titleStmt.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, August 3, 1899

bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.note: Index Bureau Dept. of State Rec'd 5 Sep '99
div1.p:
No. 34, Consular Series.
Legation of the United States,
Monrovia Liberia,
Aug. 3, 1899.

I have the honor to say, that the recent and constant racial troubles in the United States, are having the effect to greatly alienate the African (Liberian) trade from them. The principal Liberian merchants are formerly American citizens, and since the frequent outbursts of racial disturbances, in the United States, they are seeking a closer business alliance with European merchants. It is now, with difficulty, and very seldom at that, that I have the opportunity of certifying to
to a declared Invoice, of Liberian productions to a port, in the United States.

I have the honor to be
your obedient servant,
Owen L. W. Smith,
M. R. and C. General.
To
Hon. David J. Hill,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington.
